Description: Tondo sherd of Attic black-figured pottery lip cup; interior: from outside: part of alternating red and black tongue frieze: four narrow black bands; in tondo, black-figure decoration consisting of sphinx seated to right (head and part of wing missing; added white and red details on wing), no doubt resting left front paw on a tendril; three drilled repair holes; exterior glazed black.
Producer name: Attributed to: Tleson, Son of Nearchos (According to Heesen)
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Heesen attributes the sherd to Tleson's middle period. British Museum 1965,0930.858, also with a repair hole may well be from the same cup.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 128, pl. XXXIX, no. 357.2)
CVA Boston II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum USA, Fasc. 19, Museum of Fine Arts, Boston (p. 42, pl. 109, no. 13)
Heesen 2011 / Athenian Little-Master Cups (p. 200, p. 298, no. 337)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 234, no. 204)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1343) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4773 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
